Transcript: Rick Pitino talks IU, UNCW

Transcript: Q&A with Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino on Indiana, UNC-Wilmington, Chinanu Onuaku and Shaqquan Aaron.

Transcript: Rick Pitino talks IU, UNCW

Jeff Greer, jgreer@courier-journal.com 12:11 p.m. EST December 13, 2014
Buy Photo

Louisville coach Rick Pitino smiles as he jokes with reporters during his weekly press conference. December 1, 2014(Photo: Michael Clevenger/The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

58 CONNECT 8 TWEET 7 LINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Rick Pitino spoke to the media on Thursday to preview Sunday's Louisville-UNC-Wilmington game and to look back at U of L's win over Indiana on Tuesday.

Here's the full transcript from the Q&A, and the full video's at the bottom.

Opening statement: Well, it's always a special time of the year when the Billy Minardi Classic rolls around, especially with Kevin Keats coming back. He's shared a lot of great memories with us and was part of a national championship team, part of some really great runs we had and really gave a lot to our program. So we're excited to have him back in town, excited to play UNC-Wilmington. They're a team that scores a lot of points, is ranked in the top 10 in 3-point field-goal percentage and a few more offensive categories. And you all know, you've been watching college basketball the last few weeks, all the upsets that happen with dangerous teams like this. You have to take care of business at the defensive end, take good shots and make sure you execute at both ends properly. They do everything we do in terms of changing defenses, playing matchup zones, all three presses. We've had some time to prepare, and it's a good thing.

Related: Montrezl Harrell's smarts, power pay off vs. IU

On UNC-Wilmington's offense: They run a lot of different offensive sets, not too much the way we run them.

On if his players know about the upsets in college hoops: They see it, they know it. Our guys follow it, we talk about it certainly. From the moment the referee puts the ball in play, you've got to be ready at both ends of the floor and that's what you try to do.

On if there's a common thread in the upsets: I think the other team just gets hot from the 3-point line. I think that's the common thread. NJIT took some very difficult 3s and made them. If you don't take care of business defensively early in the game, the other team mounts its confidence and they think everything is going in and the rim becomes much bigger than it really is because their confidence is very high.

On the introduction of the 3-point shot on his teams: Yeah, that's exactly what I thought. I didn't think we could win at Providence right away and I said we needed, not necessarily a gimmick, but something we could hang our hat on that would overcome a lack of talent. One was relentless full-court pressure, the other was the 3-point shot. I had it a little easier back then because Villanova, Georgetown, Connecticut -- I don't think they made a 3 the first three games, and we were trying to take 18 to 25. A lot of people back then were fighting the 3-point shot, didn't want to take it, didn't believe in it. So it was to our benefit.

On the Indiana win: We told our guys at halftime, 'Look, we did some bad things, especially Wayne leaving his man strong side,' and we told them we did not want to see that in the second half. We felt if we could play at that torrid pace, generally -- not all the time -- weary legs make shots difficult.

Related: Shaqquan Aaron ready to go after NCAA reinstatement

On U of L's improving offense: What we've worked on in the last week is our passing and I think good spacing and good passing led to good offense.

On Mangok Mathiang's healthy 'comeback': Well, he's not coming back. We were not going to play him in that game, but (Chinanu Onuaku) did not pay attention to the scouting report, did not adhere to what we were trying to do defensively and hurt us. (Mathiang) gave us great effort and we needed it.

On Chris Jones and Terry Rozier's play vs. IU: I think they were both spectacular. For a 5-9, 5-10 point guard to grab nine rebounds, get steals, get the offense playing at a high pace (referring to Jones) ... It was great atmosphere. Certainly, we were outnumbered six-to-one in fans, so it was like a semi-road game. But even with that being said, it was just a tremendous atmosphere. The fans were into the game. It was a great offensive basketball contest.

On Shaqquan Aaron getting to play: I think it was big for him. Now, whether he can play for us right now, I'm not sure. He's got to improve dramatically. Sometimes you really never see someone's talents, whether they're sitting out or redshirting, because they're not as motivated. They're not playing and, when you're getting ready for scouting, they don't take an active part. So he's just now taking an active part and he's got to learn a few things before he steps on the floor. He's got to learn to play defense and he's got to also stop taking bad shots. Challenged shots lead to fast breaks for the other team, so it's a double-edged sword. Not only do you shoot a low percentage, but you enable the other team to get an easy fast break. He's improving. He's still not understanding what we want offensively and defensively. Ultimately, I think he can play more (guard) than (small forward) because he's so weak.

On Aaron earning playing time: Everything in our program -- nothing is entitled. You're not entitled to one single thing. You earn every minute you get. There's no entitlement here. Although this is an entitlement culture, we don't buy into that culture. Everything you get here, you earn. Montrezl Harrell earns every minute. Jones and Rozier earn every minute. Nobody's entitled to anything.

Related: They should play U of L-IU every year

On Harrell asking to play along the baseline more: I don't know about that. They were going a lot of zone and he roams the baseline very well against zone.

On wearing out opponents with a high tempo: I don't know if they'll lose their legs. I think they're going to shoot a lower percentage. I think they're gonna struggle from the foul line. I've been coaching a long time, and when you play at that pace, very few teams can withstand it and shoot great. Some get dunks and get inside play and still shoot a good percentage. But when you're shooting jump shots, and you're always handling the ball against pressure ... I'll have to say Chris Jones was in unbelievable physical condition for that game.

On noticing if the tempo's getting to opponents: You don't necessarily see it except when guys put their hands on their legs. But you expect it with a high pace game. You just feel that, as time goes on, it's going to happen. You're going to have your run in the press. If you don't, then obviously they're playing a lot of people and they're well-rested.

On the Billy Minardi Classic: It's like anything else, you move on but the name stays forever -- as part of the dormitory, as part of the tournament -- and it's very special to celebrate his legacy. We're always very excited having the family and friends come in. We always try to get a team in here that knows the history, has some affiliation with it, and (UNC-Wilmington coach Kevin Keatts) knows that. We always give nice gifts to the opponent. I actually let Kevin pick out the gifts this year for both teams.

On Keatts: I think he's going to take his biggest jump next year because he has four players sitting out and he had a good recruiting class. He's done a very smart thing in gathering transfers. This year, he's playing 17 road games and he could do nothing about that. So Kevin's going to do a great job. He's one of the best assistants I've had because he has everything. He's not only a great scout, great teacher and great person, he has an outstanding mind and is a tremendous recruiter, great communicator with the players, great sense of humor. He's got the total package -- incredible wife, beautiful children. It doesn't stop. We really miss him here. His personality is great. UNC-Wilmington is very lucky to have him.

On lessons learned vs. IU: It really taught us a great lesson because they sometimes on the break play five guys on the perimeter, and it's very difficult to guard those guys. They made some difficult shots and it really taught our guys something about the 3-point shot and how you have to guard it. We came in at halftime and they said, 'Coach, we're challenging them and they're still making them.' And I said, 'Yeah, they're a great shooting team. So now you've got to get after them and make them dribble the basketball.' And sometimes you give up layups, but (Mathiang) did a great job on a bad ankle of challenging and blocking shots. But passing and spacing were the reasons we shot a high percentage, and that's the thing that was absent a week ago.

On late-game free-throw shooting: Generally, if you're a great outside shooter, you'll be a great free-throw shooter. If you're a good outside shooter, you'll be a good free-throw shooter. If you're average, you're going to be average. In my recall, the only exception was Otis Birdsong, who was one of the league's best shooters but awful from the foul line. If you have a great outside shooter -- Luke Hancock, Kyle Kuric -- you're going to be a very good free-throw shooter. But we're working overtime on that. In practice, we probably take 100 (foul shots) and what it's done for us is make us a better block-out team and a better offensive rebounding team.

It's not a stat, but we do a great job of getting it back. Sometimes you'll see us make the first and miss the second and it's almost like a three-point play. We have our guards do that, for a variety of reasons. We did a lot of really good things in that game toward the end, very wise things with the clock, very wise things with our press offense in making sure our spacing was proper. It was a great game, great atmosphere.

On judging Wayne Blackshear by effort vs. shooting numbers: Wayne has not become what he was last year -- a spot-up jump shooter. He made great passes to Montrezl, he took guys off the dribble. I don't care about Wayne's shooting. He didn't play good defense until the second half. He gave up a lot of those 3s by trying to help, and you can't help from the perimeter. But Wayne played a terrific game. It was the best, with Mangok, all our guys have played. And Anas (Mahmoud) played well. (Onuaku) did not play well; he was just not in the game. The last couple of games, he has not adhered to the scouting report and paid attention coming out of timeouts what we're in. He's showing a lot of 'freshmanitis' of late.

On Mahmoud: He's got very good skills. We're trying to change his jump shot. He shoots it from here (by his neck) so when he's below the foul line, he can't get a shot off. We're trying to get it up high (above his head). It's a terrible habit. I don't know how a guy would shoot like that. (Quentin Snider) does it, too, unfortunately, and we're trying to change that as well. We keep reiterating to him that you're shooting out and, when you shoot out, you shoot a low trajectory. The first foot of your shot should be up, not out. It should be up and then out. And (Snider) and Anas and Mangok shoot out. We've corrected it with Terry and he's gotten much better. Anas has some very good skills. He's long, he passes it well. He's the best passing big man. (Onuaku's) a very good passer, but he doesn't pivot well to see the whole window opening up. He just sees through binoculars sort of.

On noticing those hitches in recruiting vs. in practice: Sometimes you notice them. Like we noticed (Snider's) defense before he came here. We noticed Shaqquan's bad shot selection. He took bad shots all the time. But with Anas, Matz (Stockman), Jaylen (Johnson) ... we didn't know their weaknesses because we didn't see them as much.

Rick Pitino talks to the media at his weekly press conference about the Billy Minardi Classic, good shooting form and his team's performance to date. Michael Clevenger, The C-J
